lead_paragraph: Elisa Y. does not need to glance at the black and white portrait of her long-dead son. Her weeping, unstaunched by time, begins without instigation. abstract: Sandra Westin knows the dread and frustration of losing a job. She knows the ache of rejection and isolation. So when she read the story of Aida D., a jobless woman who has been helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Ms. Westin's response was heartfelt.   In a letter to the fund, she offered her typewriter to Ms. D., who has been writing cover letters by hand. The story, she said, mirrored her own struggles.

keywords.value: Catholic Charities Archdiocese of New York

abstract: New York City's homeless shelters are filling up. Winter weather has been colder sooner than usual, and social service agencies' outreach efforts have been more intense, city officials and shelter workers say. Other homeless people, meanwhile, have migrated to makeshift encampments scattered throughout the boroughs to escape what advocates for the homeless have charged is a campaign to make them less visible on midtown streets. Surviving on the streets this year could be harder than ever.         There are refuges, like the drop-in center on Bond Street in downtown Brooklyn, which provides food, warmth and counseling. The private center, one of nine in the city, accepts people who walk in from the street, are picked up by the center's outreach van or are referred from Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens. The charity, which runs the center, is one of seven supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, whose 84th appeal for donations is now under way.
lead_paragraph: New York City's homeless shelters are filling up. Winter weather has been colder sooner than usual, and social service agencies' outreach efforts have been more intense, city officials and shelter workers say. Other homeless people, meanwhile, have migrated to makeshift encampments scattered throughout the boroughs to escape what advocates for the homeless have charged is a campaign to make them less visible on midtown streets. Surviving on the streets this year could be harder than ever.

abstract: Carol Ann Fuoco, 58, was a steady worker until she was laid off in March. Now a new job has proved elusive.
snippet: Carol Ann Fuoco, 58, was a steady worker until she was laid off in March. Now a new job has proved elusive.
lead_paragraph: For Carol Ann Fuoco, 58, things are not the way they used to be.

abstract: After moving to New York from Puerto Rico seeking a better education for their developmentally disabled child, a family found help, but also challenges.
snippet: After moving to New York from Puerto Rico seeking a better education for their developmentally disabled child, a family found help, but also challenges.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Acevedo and his sister, Katiria, share a bedroom in their family’s apartment near Yankee Stadium, in the Bronx. It is tight quarters for two teenagers with different interests. Katiria’s side is decorated in pink and with Hello Kitty paraphernalia. Raymond’s features sports equipment and posters of girls in bikinis.

headline.main: A Better Life Here, Yes, but Not Without Worries

abstract: For Eddy Mejia, the financial hit of a cancer diagnosis compounded an emotional strain for him, his sister and his daughter.
snippet: For Eddy Mejia, the financial hit of a cancer diagnosis compounded an emotional strain for him, his sister and his daughter.
lead_paragraph: Justina Mejia has become fluent in the language of cancer.

abstract: Saba Arain was homesick and lost when she arrived from Pakistan. But English classes and a baking program gave her the confidence she needed.
snippet: Saba Arain was homesick and lost when she arrived from Pakistan. But English classes and a baking program gave her the confidence she needed.
lead_paragraph: When Saba Arain arrived in New York from Pakistan in 2009, she left behind a teaching career and a large family. The only person she knew in the city was her husband.

headline.main: Man Who Gives Support Finds There Is Some for Him

keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: When Idi Diallo shared his story in December, he was living in a shelter with dreams of playing soccer and going to college. Readers have helped him on his way.
snippet: When Idi Diallo shared his story in December, he was living in a shelter with dreams of playing soccer and going to college. Readers have helped him on his way.
lead_paragraph: When Idi Diallo shared his story with New York Times readers in December, he was staying in a shelter in Harlem and weighing whether to pursue college or chase his lifelong dream of playing professional soccer. He was working part time at a bar to pay for plane tickets for tryouts across the country. He had several tryouts but could not afford to get to them all.

headline.main: How Readers Helped Soccer Player on Next Leg of His Journey
headline.print_headline: Lifting Hope, With Global Reach

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Evelyn Marin learned she had pancreatic cancer after having operations to remove tumors from her brain and cysts from her spine. Sidelined for months, she fell behind on her rent.
snippet: Evelyn Marin learned she had pancreatic cancer after having operations to remove tumors from her brain and cysts from her spine. Sidelined for months, she fell behind on her rent.
lead_paragraph: Evelyn Marin had been out of the hospital for less than two months — after operations on her brain and spine, and to remove her pancreas — when she received an eviction notice from her landlord.

headline.main: She Survived a Series of Health Scares. Then She Was Almost Evicted.
headline.print_headline: Widow Battling Cancer Felt ‘Useless’ Facing Eviction

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Emmanuel Morantus worked three jobs to support his family as an immigrant nearly 30 years ago, but now his failing health keeps him tied to an oxygen tank and to electricity bills he cannot afford.
snippet: Emmanuel Morantus worked three jobs to support his family as an immigrant nearly 30 years ago, but now his failing health keeps him tied to an oxygen tank and to electricity bills he cannot afford.
lead_paragraph: Wherever Emmanuel Morantus goes, a long length of plastic tubing trails behind him. Whether he is padding into his tiny bathroom or stepping outside to retrieve his mail or resting on his living room hospital bed, he always makes sure the line does not get tangled.

headline.main: Retired, Needing Oxygen and Trying to Pay His Bills
headline.print_headline: Retired, Needing Oxygen, And Trying to Pay His Bills

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Single mother with AIDS tells how she has been helped by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund (M)
snippet: Single mother with AIDS tells how she has been helped by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund (M)
lead_paragraph: With time and therapy, Angela H., a 29-year-old single mother of four, has confronted the fact that she is probably going to die of AIDS. But she has not told her two oldest children, who are 8 and 9, that they, too, are infected. They know that they and their mother are sick, but the illness does not have a name.

headline.main: A Mother Manages Children, AIDS and Dying
headline.print_headline: A Mother Manages Children, AIDS and Dying
